Subject: Re: HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=Yyhu7BQ0Wb1tqod5clG521ATpKQHJ_uxk7xRAHH91gldqc6-oBitnY6Taw

Hi, 
a have a quiestion about this.. The evolution in this indirect method =

evolves the geometry of the connections, right? But even in the first 
pop=
ulation there may be phenotypes with millions of connections. Does 
this vi=
olate the third principle of NEAT, that initial genomes must 
be as small a=
s possible? 
What about hidden nodes? In this approach, a set of nodes has =
to be 
chosen and the evolution then evolves only the connections between 
=
them. There are no additive mutations for nodes and stuff. 
I know that the=
 inner workings of this system is NEAT, starting 
minimally and so on, but =
when we look at the actual phenotypes, when 
we see how they evolve, it doe=
sn't look like NEAT starting from a 
minimal point and slowly adding struct=
ure.. A single small mutation 
in the CPPN genome changes the entire struct=
ure of the phenotype. Is 
this right?
Or the comlexification here is about =
moving to higher resolutions of 
the networks? 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Hi everyone, as some =
of you know, we have been working for a while 
> now on turning the pattern=
s output by CPPNs into neural networks.  
> 
> I am excited to report that =
we have found a 
> straightforward and principled approach to interpreting =
CPPN output 
> as a connectivity pattern rather than a spatial pattern.    =
We are 
> calling this method HyperNEAT, which stands for Hypercube-based 
=
> NEAT.  With HyperNEAT, we have been able to produce working neural 
> net=
works with millions of connections.
> 
> Because we have just recently had =
two publications on this method 
> accepted at GECCO-2007, we can finally d=
isclose our work and share 
> it with others.  The publications are availab=
le on 
> the "Publications" page at http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu 
> 
> They are =
also available through my homepage 
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#publ=
ications (under Publications, 
> Conference and Symposium Papers), or direc=
tly at the following 
> address, which I am sure yahoo is going to mangle:
=
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
> option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&=
id=3D14&Itemid=3D28
> 
> The two papers, which present separate experiments=
 are:
> 
> "Generating Large-Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering 
> G=
eometric Regularities" by Jason J. Gauci and Kenneth O. Stanley
> 
> and 
>=
 
> "A Novel Generative Encoding for Exploiting Neural Network Sensor 
> an=
d Output Geometry" by David B. D'Ambrosio and Kenneth O. Stanley
> 
> David=
 D'Ambriosio and Jason Gauci are both Ph.D. students in the 
> EPlex lab wh=
o did an enormous amount of work to make this possible.
> 
> HyperNEAT is b=
ased on a surprisingly simple principle: Connectivity 
> patterns are actua=
lly no different from spatial patterns in a 
higher-
> dimensional space.  =
In other words, a 2-dimensional connectivity 
> pattern is the same thing a=
s a 4-dimensional spatial pattern.  (The 
> technical term is that they are=
 "isomorphic.")  Therefore, if we 
> simply produce spatial patterns within=
 a 4D hypercube instead of a 
> 2D plane, they can be mapped directly to co=
nnectivity patterns with 
> all the nice properties that we have seen from =
CPPNs.  Thus, they 
> require no special "image recognition" type tricks.  =
The mapping is 
> perfectly isomorphic.  We are calling these 4D CPPNs "con=
nective 
> CPPNs" since they are interpreted as connectivity patterns.
> 
>=
 This insight yields a handful of unprecedented capabilities.  For 
> examp=
le, with connective CPPNs, you can recreate the same solution 
> network at=
 a different resolution without further evolution!  You 
> can also place i=
nputs and outputs in meaningful geometric 
> configurations that HyperNEAT =
can exploit for symmetries and 
> regularities.  
> 
> In any case, I am ex=
cited about this new advance and these papers 
> are a first step in explor=
ing the new approach.
> 
> ken
>
